natural problem: Express this sum as a common fraction: $.\overline{8} + .\overline{2}$
natural solution: In general, to express the number $0.\overline{n}$ as a fraction, we call it $x$ and subtract it from $10x$: $$\begin{array}{r r c r@{}l} &10x &=& n&.nnnnn\ldots \\ - &x &=& 0&.nnnnn\ldots \\ \hline &9x &=& n &
Hence, our original problem reduces to computing $\frac 89 + \frac 29 = \boxed{\frac{10}{9}}$.

and h1 : "b = 2 / 9"
shows  "a + b = 10 / 9"

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = sum (\<lambda>i. 8 / 10 ^ i) {1..}"
and h1 : "y = sum (\<lambda>i. 2 / 10 ^ i) {1..}"
shows  "x + y = 10 / 9"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Express this sum as a common fraction: $.\overline{8} + .\overline{2}$ The final Answer is \frac{10}{9}
 ### Proof
 In general, to express the number $0.\overline{n}$ as a fraction, we call it $x$ and subtract it from $10x$: $$\begin{array}{r r c r@{}l} &10x &=& n&.nnnnn\ldots \\ - &x &=& 0&.nnnnn\ldots \\ \hline &9x &=& n &
 \end{array}$$ This shows that $0.\overline{n} = \frac{n}{9}$.
 Hence, our original problem reduces to computing $\frac 89 + \frac 29 = \boxed{\frac{10}{9}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = sum (\<lambda>i. 8 / 10 ^ i) {1..}"
and h1 : "y = sum (\<lambda>i. 2 / 10 ^ i) {1..}"
shows  "x + y = 10 / 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given that x is the sum of the series with terms 8 / 10^i starting from i = 1 to infinity and y is the sum of the series with terms 2 / 10^i starting from i = 1 to infinity, what is x + y? The final answer is 10 / 9.
